title: 103_hr222
content: The Act is titled the "Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993" and includes provisions for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993 allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority in special messages to Congress on the same day an appropriation bill is approved. Each message can only propose rescinding one item of budget authority and must specify certain details about the item. The Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993 enables the President to propose rescinding budget authority through special messages to Congress. Each message must be accompanied by a draft bill or joint resolution that would rescind the proposed budget authority. The majority leader of the House where the budget authority originated introduces the draft bill or joint resolution on the same day the special message is transmitted. The Line-Item Rescission Act of 1993 allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority through special messages to Congress. The draft bill or joint resolution introduced in the House or Senate must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations and reported within 20 days of continuous session. Failure to report within the specified period results in automatic discharge from consideration. A bill or joint resolution introduced in Congress must be voted on within 30 days of continuous session. If passed, it is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House on the same day. A bill or joint resolution must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives or the Senate within 20 days of transmission. The committee must report the bill without substantive revision within this timeframe, or it will be automatically discharged from consideration. A bill or joint resolution must be voted on within 30 days of transmission to a House of Congress. If passed, it is returned to the originating House for further action. The House of Representatives has specific rules for considering bills and joint resolutions, including privileged motions and limited debate time. The House of Representatives has rules for considering bills and joint resolutions, including limited debate time and decisions made without debate on motions and appeals related to the procedure. The House of Representatives has rules for considering bills and joint resolutions, including limited debate time and decisions made without debate on motions and appeals related to the procedure. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 10 hours, with time divided between the majority leader and the minority leader or their designees. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders. No further debate allowed on motions or appeals related to bills or joint resolutions under this section. Amendments are prohibited, and any budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation within 60 days. The text chunk discusses the conditions under which budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation within 60 days unless both Houses of Congress agree to the bill or joint resolution. Definitions for terms like 'item', 'appropriation bill', and 'appropriation Act' are provided. Conforming amendments are also mentioned. The text chunk amends section 1012 and 1013 of the Act, specifying time periods for obligation of budget authority. Section 1011 is further amended by striking out certain references. The text chunk further amends section 1012 and 1013 of the Act by updating references to time periods for budget authority obligation. The text chunk updates references in section 1012 and 1013 of the Act regarding budget authority obligation time periods. Amendments include redesignating subparagraphs and inserting new requirements for transmitting special messages under section 1013. Section 1015 is also amended to include reference to section 1014. Section 1016 is amended as well. Section 1016 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1013(e) and 1014(b). The table of sections is also amended to reflect these changes. Insert new item after section 1012 in the table of sections. SEC. 3. APPLICATION. The amendments made by this section apply to budget authority provided by appropriation Acts that become law after the enactment of this Act.
